title: FIRST RECORD OF SOREX TENELLUS FROM THE CENTRAL GREAT BASIN
abstract: BioOne Complete (complete.BioOne.org) is a full-text database of 200 subscribed and open-access titles in the biological, ecological, and environmental sciences published by nonprofit societies, associations, museums, institutions, and presses.

body_text.text: FIG. 1 Map of intermountain region with locality records for Sorex tenellus (solid squares) and S. nanus (solid circles). New record for S. tenellus indicated by a star. Records compiled from Hall (1946) , Hoffmann and Taber (1960) , Brown (1967) , Hoffmann et al. (1969) , Armstrong (1972) , Armstrong et al. (1973) , Findley et al. (1975) , Spencer (1975) , Thompson (1977) , Cinq-Mars et al. (1979) , Hoffmann and Owen (1980) , Kirkland (1981) , Clark and Stromberg (1987) , Williams (1991) , Kirkland et al. (1997) , Rickart and Heaney (2001) , and Hafner and Stahlecker (2002) .

The dwarf shrew (Sorex nanus) and Inyo shrew (Sorex tenellus) are among the smallest of North American insectivores, weighing Յ4 g (Hoffmann and Owen, 1980; Hoffmann, 1999a Hoffmann, , 1999b . Morphological and biochemical similarities indicate that they are recently diverged sister taxa (Hoffmann and Owen, 1980; George, 1988) . Because they are seldom captured in conventional small mammal traps, these tiny shrews have been perceived as rare. However, recent surveys using pitfall traps have produced many additional records of both species (Williams, 1991; Kirkland et al., 1997; Rickart and Heaney, 2001 ).

On 24 July 2000, we captured a small specimen of Sorex while conducting a survey for small mammals in the east-central portion of Great Basin National Park in the southern Snake Range, White Pine County, Nevada (Fig.  1) . The shrew was taken in Englemann spruce (Picea engelmannii) forest at 9,900 ft (ca. 3,000 m) along the southern fork of Lehman Creek, 0.6 km N, 0.5 km E of Teresa Lake (39Њ00Ј31ЉN, 114Њ18Ј15ЉW). It was captured in a simple pitfall trap constructed from an empty 355-mL aluminum beverage can (Rickart and Heaney, 2001 ). The pitfall was positioned along a runway on the margin of a decomposing fallen log in an area with moist, rocky soil and abundant organic detritus. Other traps at this locality captured several specimens of Sorex vagrans, a species common throughout the Snake Range (Hall, 1946 ; unpublished records of the Field Museum and the Utah Museum of Natural History).

The specimen (UMNH 30288) is a young female preserved in fluid with the skull removed and cleaned. Measurements (mm) are: total length, 92; tail length, 37; hindfoot length (including claws), 10; condylobasal length, 15.1; weight 2.3 g. Both in weight and hindfoot length, the specimen is smaller than most S. tenellus (Merriam, 1895 (Merriam, , 1902 Hoffmann and Owen, 1980) , but this is probably due to its young age. The specimen resembles the syntopic S. vagrans in the relative size of the unicuspid teeth (U3 smaller than U4), but the presence of a small medial tine located well within the pigmented region of I1 together with the small size clearly distinguish it from that species. It was identified as S. tenellus (not S. nanus) based on its larger skull size (condylobasal length Ͼ14.8 mm) and slightly inflated (rather than flattened) cranium ( Junge and Hoffmann, 1981) , and by direct comparison to the holotypes of both S. tenellus and S. nanus, as well as other specimens housed at the United States National Museum of Natural History and the Utah Museum of Natural History. This is the first record of S. tenellus from the central Great Basin (Fig. 1) . It represents the northeasternmost record for the species and a range extension of ca. 300 km NE of the nearest previous record from Rainier Mesa, Nye County, Nevada ( Jorgensen and Hayward, 1963) . The new locality is ca. 400 km SW and ca. 400 km NW of the nearest known localities of S. nanus in Utah and Arizona (Fig. 1) . Thus, it is unlikely to provide evidence supporting purported intergradation between the 2 species (Hoffmann and Owen, 1980) . Although most records of S. tenellus are from montane sites, the species has been found in relatively arid habitat at lower elevations, suggesting relatively broad ecological tolerance (Hoffmann and Owen, 1980) . Sorex tenellus probably occurs on other isolated mountain ranges within the central Great Basin and should be sought there. Detection of this species is of special importance because of the role of Great Basin montane small mammals as one of the primary exemplars used in debates regarding island biogeography (e.g., Brown, 1971; Lomolino and Davis, 1997) and especially the role of in-complete sampling on interpretation of data and patterns (Grayson et al., 1996; Lawlor, 1998) . The occurrence of S. tenellus in the central Great Basin represents an eastward extension of the Sierra Nevada fauna as opposed to a western extension of the Rocky Mountain fauna (exemplified by S. nanus). Another montane mammal, the pika (Ochotona princeps), shows a similar pattern, in which the Sierra Nevada form extends across the southern Great Basin into southern Utah, whereas the Rocky Mountain form extends westward into northeastern Nevada (Hafner and Sullivan, 1995) .
